dublinCore.dc:title: 117 HR 6738 IH: Retirement Tax Credit Parity for Cooperatives and Charities Act
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Kind (for himself and Mr. Kelly of Pennsylvania) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means

form.official-title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide a CSEC employee tax credit.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Retirement Tax Credit Parity for Cooperatives and Charities Act.

subsection.text: Subpart A of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by inserting after section 25D the following new section:

In the case of an eligible individual, there shall be allowed as a credit against the tax imposed by this subtitle for the taxable year an amount equal to 10 percent of so much of the employer retirement savings contributions made on behalf of the eligible individual for the plan year ending with or within such taxable year as do not exceed $1,000.
For purposes of this section, the term eligible individual means any individual who is eligible to participate in a CSEC defined contribution plan.

For purposes of this section, with respect to any employee, the term employer retirement savings contributions means the amount of employer contributions (other than elective deferrals as defined in section 402(g)(3)) made to a CSEC defined contribution plan on behalf of such employee.
For purposes of this section, the term CSEC defined contribution plan means a defined contribution plan which—

paragraph.text: as of July 26, 2005, would be an eligible cooperative plan, as defined in section 104(c) of the Pension Protection Act of 2006, if such section applied to defined contribution plans,
as of January 1, 2021, was maintained by an employer that also participated in an eligible cooperative plan, as defined in section 104(c) of the Pension Protection Act of 2006,
would be described in subparagraph (B), (C), or (D) of section 414(y)(1) but for the fact that it is a defined contribution plan, or
as of January 1, 2021, was maintained by an employer that also participated in a plan described in subparagraph (B), (C), or (D) of section 414(y)(1).

subsection.text: In the case of any taxable year beginning after December 31, 2022, the $1,000 amount in subsection (a) shall be increased by an amount equal to—

paragraph.text: the cost-of-living adjustment determined under section 1(f)(3) for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins, determined by substituting calendar year 2021 for calendar year 2016 in subparagraph (A)(ii) thereof.

subsection.continuation-text: Any increase determined under the preceding sentence shall be rounded to the nearest multiple of $50.

subsection.text: The amendment made by this section shall apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2021.
